Title: Aligning Agent Communication Protocols - A Pragmatic Approach
Venue: International Conference on Software and Data Technologies
Abstract summary: The paper presents a pragmatic approach for aligning agent communication protocol primitives by analyzing their usage, rather than just relying on syntactical classification.

Title: Issues in Human–Agent Communication
Authors: M. Barnes, Shan G. Lakhmani, E. Holder, Jessie Y.C. Chen
Abstract summary: Current agent protocol primitives are limited in representing nuanced human operational expertise and communication patterns due to differences in reasoning processes, capabilities, and knowledge bases between humans and agents.

Title: MCP: Learning Composable Hierarchical Control with Multiplicative Compositional Policies
Authors: X. B. Peng, Michael Chang, Grace Zhang, P. Abbeel, S. Levine
Abstract summary: The paper proposes a method called multiplicative compositional policies (MCP) to learn reusable motor skills that can be composed to produce a large variety of complex behaviors.

Title: Identifying Requirements for Effective Human-Automation Teamwork
Authors: J. Joe, J. O'Hara, H. Medema, J. Oxstrand
Abstract summary: Current agent protocol primitives have limitations in representing nuanced human operational expertise and communication patterns for effective human-automation teamwork.

Title: “Agent A, Can You Pass the Salt?” The Role of Pragmatics in Agent Communication
Authors: H. Holmback, M. Greaves, J. Bradshaw
Abstract summary: Current agent communication languages have limitations in representing the pragmatics of human communication.

Title: Addressing the Limitations of Protocol Analysis in the Study of Complex Human Behavior
Abstract summary: The paper discusses limitations of protocol analysis in studying complex human behavior, but does not address the limitations of current agent protocol primitives.

Title: Commitment-based and dialogue-game-based protocols: new trends in agent communication languages
Abstract summary: Current agent communication protocols have limitations in representing flexible and nuanced human communication patterns.

Title: Community Standards for Agent Communication
Abstract summary: Current agent communication protocols are limited in representing nuanced human communication patterns, and a community-driven approach to defining standards is needed.
